On Fri, 18 Aug 2006 at 06:45:27, Simon Chappell wrote:

> On 8/18/06, kults=
tatus77 <onlineguy@...> wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I'm quite familiar with t=
he purpose of tearDown(), I just fail to see
> > the necessity of it. Accor=
ding to M. Feathers' "Working effectively
> > with legacy code" unit tests =
don't access databases or communicate via
> > a nreal network connection. I=
 do know that his book's focus is not on
> > JUnit, but I do think that he =
has a point there. So: without a
> > database and a network connection, whe=
n it is really necessary to free
> > up resources with tearDown()? Isn't ga=
rbage collecting enough?
> 

Here's an example for you.

I run unit tests o=
n custom UI components, some of which require a visible
window.  The OS has=
 a limited number of these, so my tests running successfully
depends on tim=
ely disposal of these windows.  Some tests, in fact, depend on a
certain wi=
ndow configuration, so if a previous test leaves stuff behind, it can
inter=
fere with subsequent tests.

Here's another example:
The JUnit 3 test runne=
rs create all test cases before running, and keep
references to them in mem=
ory after running.  Anything kept as field references
in a test class will =
not be GC'd until the test runner releases the test class
reference (which =
is never).
